title: Celypha woodiana
text:
Celypha woodiana also known as the mistletoe marble is a <a href="moth">moth</a> of the family <a href="Tortricidae">Tortricidae</a> found in Europe. In <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> the moth is a priority species in the <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Biodiversity%20Action%20Plan">United Kingdom Biodiversity Action Plan</a>.
Description.
Wingspan c. 17mm. The moths fly in July and August and can be found resting on tree trunks during the day. They also come to <a href="Moth%20trap">light</a>.
Eggs can be found on mistletoe ("<a href="Viscum%20album">Viscum album</a>") in September and October.
Larvae can be found from September to May in a <a href="Leaf%20mine">mine</a>. The initial mine is inconspicuous as a brown, narrow, lower-surface corridor and the larva can leave the mine and start a new one elsewhere. In April and May the larva make a full depth transparent blotch with most of the <a href="frass">frass</a> ejected. The mines can be difficult to find as the leaf falls from the plant.
Larvae pupate in June, in a loose cocoon amongst <a href="lichen">lichen</a>s or under the bark of the host tree.
Distribution and habitat.
The moth is found from <a href="Great%20Britain">Great Britain</a> to the <a href="Ukraine">Ukraine</a> but is absent in some countries, including the <a href="Netherlands">Netherlands</a>, <a href="Portugal">Portugal</a> and <a href="Spain">Spain</a>.
In England the moth has been found in the following counties; <a href="Gloucestershire">Gloucestershire</a>, <a href="Herefordshire">Herefordshire</a>, <a href="Somerset">Somerset</a>, <a href="Warwickshire">Warwickshire</a> and <a href="Worcestershire">Worcestershire</a>. The moth was found in <a href="Wales">Wales</a> for the first time in 2019 with leaf mines and a larva at <a href="Magor%20Marsh">Magor Marsh</a> (), a <a href="Gwent%20Wildlife%20Trust">Gwent Wildlife Trust</a> nature reserve. It is rare and mostly confined to mature <a href="apple">apple</a> ("Malus" spp) <a href="orchard">orchard</a>s in southern England and the south <a href="Midlands">Midlands</a>. Mistletoe on <a href="Crataegus">hawthorn</a> ("Crataegus" spp) is the next preferred host tree and it has also been found on pear ("<a href="Pyrus%20communis">Pyrus communis</a>"), crack willow ("<a href="Salix%20fragilis">Salix fragilis</a>") and rowan ("<a href="Sorbus%20aucuparia">Sorbus aucuparia</a>") which has been planted. The moth seems to prefer succulent specimens and is able to survive on isolated clumps of mistletoe.
Conservation.
In Great Britain the moth is subject to a <a href="United%20Kingdom%20Biodiversity%20Action%20Plan">Biodiversity action plan</a> (UK BAP species). Traditional orchards which are a UK Biodiversity Action Plan Priority habitat and the preferred habitat of the moth are in decline. Known and potential sites should be protected.
